# Effect of outliers (section 2)

## Sample without outliers
```{r}
mu <- 1 # hypothesis
obs <- c(1, 1.5, 1.6, 1.8, 2, 2.2, 2.4, 2.7)
tres <- t.test(obs, mu = mu)
```

sd = `r sd(obs)`;  
*T* = `r tres$statistic`;  
*p* = `r tres$p.value`;  
CI = [`r tres$conf.int[1]`, `r tres$conf.int[2]`].    

## Sample with one outlier
```{r}
mu <- 1 # hypothesis
obs <- c(1, 1.5, 1.6, 1.8, 2, 2.2, 2.4, 2.7, 8)
tres <- t.test(obs, mu = mu)
```

sd = `r sd(obs)`;  
*T* = `r tres$statistic`;    
*p* = `r tres$p.value`;    
CI = [`r tres$conf.int[1]`, `r tres$conf.int[2]`].  

# Effect of outliers (section 3)

## Example 1

### 2 SD rule
```{r}
a <- c(1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 6, 100, 100)
((a - mean(a)) / sd(a)) > 2
```

### Boxplot rule
```{r}
out <- boxplot(a)
out$out
```

### MAD-median rule
```{r}
((a - median(a)) / mad(a)) > 2.24 
```


## Example 2

### 2 SD rule
```{r}
a <- c(1.85, 1.11, 1.11, 0.37, 0.37, 1.85, 71.53, 71.53)
((a - mean(a)) / sd(a)) > 2
```

### Boxplot rule
```{r}
out <- boxplot(a)
out$out
```

### MAD-median rule
```{r}
((a - median(a)) / mad(a)) > 2.24 
```
